clusters.title: Rescuers save worker from partially collapsed medieval tower in Rome
clusters.neutral_headline: Rescuers Save Worker from Collapsed Medieval Tower in Rome

items.title: Rescuers save worker from partially collapsed medieval tower in Rome
items.standfirst: Rescuers in Rome on Monday pulled alive a worker trapped when a medieval tower partly collapsed during renovation, city authorities said. The man was taken to hospital with injuries. Prefect Lamberto Giannini described the effort as a “long rescue mission.”
items.content: Rescuers in Rome on Monday pulled alive a worker trapped when a medieval tower partly collapsed during renovation, city authorities said. The man was taken to hospital with injuries. Prefect Lamberto Giannini described the effort as a “long rescue mission.”

items.title: Rescuers free man trapped in partly collapsed medieval tower in Rome
items.standfirst: Worker taken to hospital after being rescued from collapsed Torre dei Conti, which was undergoing restoration worksA worker who became trapped when a medieval tower in Rome partly collapsed has been rescued, city authorities said.The man was injured and taken to hospital. Rome’s mayor, Roberto Gualtieri, said: “We hope that he will pull through.” The Rome prefect, Lamberto Giannini, told reporters the man was pulled from the rubble after “a long rescue mission”. Continue reading...
items.content: Worker taken to hospital after being rescued from collapsed Torre dei Conti, which was undergoing restoration worksA worker who became trapped when a medieval tower in Rome partly collapsed has been rescued, city authorities said.The man was injured and taken to hospital. Rome’s mayor, Roberto Gualtieri, said: “We hope that he will pull through.” The Rome prefect, Lamberto Giannini, told reporters the man was pulled from the rubble after “a long rescue mission”. Continue reading...

items.title: Historic Roman tower partially collapses during renovations
items.standfirst: The historic Torre dei Conti in Rome, Italy, partially collapsed twice on Monday during renovations, trapping at least one worker in the rubble and critically injuring another. These videos show the moment of the second collapse and its aftermath.
items.content: The historic Torre dei Conti in Rome, Italy, partially collapsed twice on Monday during renovations, trapping at least one worker in the rubble and critically injuring another. These videos show the moment of the second collapse and its aftermath.

items.title: Watch: Moment medieval tower partially collapses in Rome
items.standfirst: The partial collapse of the Torre dei Conti - close to the Colosseum - has trapped one man and left another critically injured.
items.content: The partial collapse of the Torre dei Conti - close to the Colosseum - has trapped one man and left another critically injured.

items.title: Medieval tower partially collapses in central Rome
items.standfirst: The Torre dei Conti medieval tower in central #Rome was under renovation when it partially collapsed on November 3 just after 11:30 am local time. One worker is believed to be trapped alive under rubble, while three others were evacuated, with one taken to hospital in critical condition, a firefighter spokesman told AFP. The tower is in a busy area, just off the Imperial Forum and close to the #Colosseum, #Italy's top tourist site.
items.content: The Torre dei Conti medieval tower in central #Rome was under renovation when it partially collapsed on November 3 just after 11:30 am local time. One worker is believed to be trapped alive under rubble, while three others were evacuated, with one taken to hospital in critical condition, a firefighter spokesman told AFP. The tower is in a busy area, just off the Imperial Forum and close to the #Colosseum, #Italy's top tourist site.

items.content: The Torre dei Conti partially collapsed in Rome during renovations, critically injuring one worker and trapping another.

items.title: Worker rescued from collapsed medieval tower after 11 hours trapped in rubble
items.standfirst: A man is in a critical condition after he was rescued from the rubble of a collapsed medieval tower in central Rome on Monday.
items.content: A man is in a critical condition after he was rescued from the rubble of a collapsed medieval tower in central Rome on Monday.

items.title: Worker reportedly hurt as medieval tower partially collapses in Rome

items.content: The 13th century Torre dei Conti in Rome partially collapsed during renovation work, leaving at least one worker seriously injured.

ai_summary: A worker was rescued after being trapped in a partially collapsed medieval tower in Rome.
The Torre dei Conti partially collapsed during renovations, trapping the worker for hours.
The worker was taken to the hospital with injuries after the rescue operation.
The collapse occurred near the Roman Forum, close to the Colosseum.
Authorities described the rescue as a "long rescue mission" to free the trapped worker.

clusters.title: Americans ‘dumbfounded by cruelty’ of Trump officials slashing Snap benefits
clusters.neutral_headline: Americans Worry About SNAP Benefit Cuts Amid Government Shutdown

items.title: Americans ‘dumbfounded by cruelty’ of Trump officials slashing Snap benefits
items.standfirst: Those among the 42 million enrolled in the program worry that cutoff of the benefit will send their lives into a tailspinAcross the country, Americans who depend on government help to buy groceries are preparing for the worst.As a result of the ongoing federal government shutdown, Donald Trump has threatened to, for the first time in the program’s more than 60-year history, cut off benefits provided by the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance program (Snap). A federal judge last week prevented the US Department of Agriculture from suspending Snap altogether, but the Trump administration now says enrollees will receive only half of their usual benefits. Continue reading...
items.content: Those among the 42 million enrolled in the program worry that cutoff of the benefit will send their lives into a tailspinAcross the country, Americans who depend on government help to buy groceries are preparing for the worst.As a result of the ongoing federal government shutdown, Donald Trump has threatened to, for the first time in the program’s more than 60-year history, cut off benefits provided by the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance program (Snap). A federal judge last week prevented the US Department of Agriculture from suspending Snap altogether, but the Trump administration now says enrollees will receive only half of their usual benefits. Continue reading...

items.title: White House to offer reduced food aid during shutdown after court order
items.standfirst: The government will offer partial food assistance to 42 million low-income Americans after federal courts last week ordered the Trump administration to use emergency funds for the payments during the shutdown, the White House said Monday. The emergency funds cover about half of the food aid budget for November.
items.content: The government will offer partial food assistance to 42 million low-income Americans after federal courts last week ordered the Trump administration to use emergency funds for the payments during the shutdown, the White House said Monday. The emergency funds cover about half of the food aid budget for November.

items.content: The U.S. Department of Agriculture told a federal court that it will tap into a contingency fund to allow states to issue partial SNAP benefits.

items.title: Trump administration will tap emergency fund to pay partial food stamp benefits

items.content: The shutdown has deprived more than 40 million Americans of food assistance, known as Snap, since Saturday.

items.title: SNAP benefits will restart, but will be half the normal payment and delayed
items.standfirst: About 1 in 8 U.S. residents get an average of $187 a month per person in the food assistance known as SNAP. For the first time, the Trump administration stopped the payments due at the beginning of the month.
items.content: About 1 in 8 U.S. residents get an average of $187 a month per person in the food assistance known as SNAP. For the first time, the Trump administration stopped the payments due at the beginning of the month.(Image credit: Hart Van Denburg)

ai_summary: Americans relying on SNAP benefits are preparing for potential cuts due to the shutdown.

A federal judge previously prevented a complete suspension of SNAP benefits.
The USDA prohibited grocery stores from offering special discounts to SNAP recipients.
SNAP recipients are reportedly ready to reduce spending due to the situation.

clusters.title: Powerful 6.3 earthquake hits northern Afghanistan, killing 20 and damaging historic Blue Mosque
clusters.neutral_headline: Earthquake in Afghanistan Kills 20, Damages Historic Mosque

items.title: Powerful 6.3 earthquake hits northern Afghanistan, killing 20 and damaging historic Blue Mosque
items.standfirst: A powerful 6.3 magnitude earthquake shook northern Afghanistan before dawn Monday, killing at least 20 people and injuring more than 640 others, as well as damaging the historic Blue Mosque, officials said.
items.content: A powerful 6.3 magnitude earthquake shook northern Afghanistan before dawn Monday, killing at least 20 people and injuring more than 640 others, as well as damaging the historic Blue Mosque, officials said.

items.title: Powerful Afghan earthquake leaves at least 20 dead and hundreds injured
items.standfirst: Northern provinces of Balkh and Samangan worst hit by magnitude 6.3 quake, which also damaged Mazar-i-Sharif’s Blue MosqueA powerful 6.3 magnitude earthquake shook northern Afghanistan before dawn on Monday, killing at least 20 people and injuring more than 640 others, 25 critically, a disaster management official said. Health officials said the numbers could rise.The US Geological Survey said the quake’s epicentre was located 22km (14 miles) south-west of the town of Khulm, and that it struck at 12.59am at a depth of 28km (17 miles). Continue reading...

Health officials said the numbers could rise.The US Geological Survey said the quake’s epicentre was located 22km (14 miles) south-west of the town of Khulm, and that it struck at 12.59am at a depth of 28km (17 miles). Continue reading...

The earthquake's epicenter was located southwest of Khulm, Afghanistan.
The Taliban reported the casualties and the earthquake's impact.

clusters.title: Israel says arrested ex-military prosecutor after leaked abuse video
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Arrests Ex-Military Lawyer for Leaking Abuse Video

items.title: Israel says arrested ex-military prosecutor after leaked abuse video
items.standfirst: Israeli police arrested former military prosecutor Yifat Tomer-Yerushalmi, the national security minister said Monday, following a scandal that erupted after she leaked a video appearing to show soldiers abusing a Palestinian detainee. Tomer-Yerushalmi disappeared for several hours on Sunday after she announced her resignation, with speculation swirling in the press of a possible suicide attempt. FRANCE 24's Jennie Shin reports.
items.content: Israeli police arrested former military prosecutor Yifat Tomer-Yerushalmi, the national security minister said Monday, following a scandal that erupted after she leaked a video appearing to show soldiers abusing a Palestinian detainee. Tomer-Yerushalmi disappeared for several hours on Sunday after she announced her resignation, with speculation swirling in the press of a possible suicide attempt. FRANCE 24's Jennie Shin reports.

items.title: Israel arrests ex-army lawyer for leaking video showing Palestinian’s abuse

items.content: Israel has arrested Yifat Tomer-Yerushalmi over her leaking of a video showing Israeli soldiers abusing prisoners.

items.title: Former top lawyer of Israeli army arrested for leaking video of prisoner abuse
items.standfirst: Israeli police arrested the military's former top lawyer, Yifat Tomer-Yerushalmi, who leaked a video showing the abuse of a Palestinian detainee. The video has triggered international outrage. France 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.
items.content: Israeli police arrested the military's former top lawyer, Yifat Tomer-Yerushalmi, who leaked a video showing the abuse of a Palestinian detainee. The video has triggered international outrage. France 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.

items.title: Israel top military lawyer arrested after she admitted leaking video of soldiers’ abuse
items.standfirst: Rightwing politicians and pundits have called the soldiers accused of attack on Palestinian detainee ‘heroes’ and military investigators traitors Police in Israel have arrested and detained the military’s top legal officer after she admitted leaking footage of soldiers allegedly attacking a Palestinian detainee and then in effect lying about her actions to Israel’s high court.The military advocate general, Yifat Tomer-Yerushalmi, said in a resignation letter last week that she had authorised publication of the video to defuse attacks on military investigators and prosecutors working on the case. Continue reading...

Plus, Xiaomi's pivot from smartphones to electric vehicles may have come at a human cost. And, Palantir’s earnings are expected to show continued excitement for AI and defense tech. (Source: Bloomberg)

items.title: ChatGPT owner OpenAI signs $38bn cloud computing deal with Amazon
items.standfirst: The seven-year agreement will see OpenAI gain access to Nvidia graphics processors to train its artificial intelligence models.
items.content: The seven-year agreement will see OpenAI gain access to Nvidia graphics processors to train its artificial intelligence models.

items.title: OpenAI signs massive AI compute deal with Amazon
items.standfirst: Deal will provide access to hundreds of thousands of Nvidia chips that power ChatGPT.
items.content: On Monday, OpenAI announced it has signed a seven-year, $38 billion deal to buy cloud services from Amazon Web Services to power products like ChatGPT and Sora. It’s the company’s first big computing deal after a fundamental restructuring last week that gave OpenAI more operational and financial freedom from Microsoft. The agreement gives OpenAI access to hundreds of thousands of Nvidia graphics processors to train and run its AI models. “Scaling frontier AI requires massive, reliable compute,” OpenAI CEO Sam Altman said in a statement. “Our partnership with AWS strengthens the broad compute ecosystem that will power this next era and bring advanced AI to everyone.” OpenAI will reportedly use Amazon Web Services immediately, with all planned capacity set to come online by the end of 2026 and room to expand further in 2027 and beyond. Amazon plans to roll out hundreds of thousands of chips, including Nvidia’s GB200 and GB300 AI accelerators, in data clusters built to power ChatGPT’s responses, generate AI videos, and train OpenAI’s next wave of models.Read full article Comments

items.title: Microsoft to Buy AI Computing Power From IREN for $9.7 Billion
items.standfirst: Microsoft Corp. has signed a roughly $9.7 billion deal to buy artificial intelligence computing capacity from IREN Ltd., becoming the Australian company’s largest customer. Bloomberg's Caroline Hyde reports. (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: Microsoft Corp. has signed a roughly $9.7 billion deal to buy artificial intelligence computing capacity from IREN Ltd., becoming the Australian company’s largest customer. Bloomberg's Caroline Hyde reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

items.content: Amazon Web Services has signed a $38 billion deal to supply OpenAI with computing power. This includes providing access to hundreds of thousands of Nvidia graphics processing units. Bloomberg's Caroline Hyde reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

The deal highlights the growing demand for AI computing resources.

items.title: Diane Ladd Dead At 89: Laura Dern Leads Tributes To Her Star Mother
items.standfirst: Diane Ladd, a three-time Academy Award nominee known for her fierce wit, emotional depth and commanding presence in films such as “Alice Doesn’t Live Here Anymore” and “Wild at Heart,” has died. She was 89. Ladd’s death was announced Monday by her daughter, actor Laura Dern, who said her mother…

items.title: Diane Ladd, Oscar-nominated actor and mother of Laura Dern, dies at 89
items.standfirst: Diane Ladd, the prolific actor who earned three Academy Award nominations, died Monday. She was 89.
items.content: Diane Ladd, the prolific actor who earned three Academy Award nominations, died Monday. She was 89.

items.title: From the archives: Diane Ladd and Laura Dern
items.standfirst: Three-time Oscar-nominated actress Diane Ladd, who appeared with her daughter Laura Dern in several productions (including "Rambling Rose" and "Wild at Heart"), died on Nov. 3, 2025 at age 89. In this "Sunday Morning" interview that aired May 14, 2023, the two talked with Rita Braver about a shared family history that played out on movie and TV screens, and about their joint memoir, "Honey, Baby, Mine: A Mother and Daughter Talk Life, Death, Love (and Banana Pudding)."
items.content: Three-time Oscar-nominated actress Diane Ladd, who appeared with her daughter Laura Dern in several productions (including "Rambling Rose" and "Wild at Heart"), died on Nov. 3, 2025 at age 89. In this "Sunday Morning" interview that aired May 14, 2023, the two talked with Rita Braver about a shared family history that played out on movie and TV screens, and about their joint memoir, "Honey, Baby, Mine: A Mother and Daughter Talk Life, Death, Love (and Banana Pudding)."

items.title: Diane Ladd, Oscar-nominated actor of Alice Doesn’t Live Here Anymore, dies aged 89
items.standfirst: The death of the three-time Oscar nominee, whose starred in films including Chinatown, was announced by her daughter Laura DernOscar-nominated actor Diane Ladd has died at the age of 89.The actor, whose credits included Alice Doesn’t Live Here Anymore, Chinatown and National Lampoon’s Christmas Vacation, died at her home in Ojai, California. The news was announced in a statement shared by her daughter, Oscar-winning actor Laura Dern. Continue reading...
items.content: The death of the three-time Oscar nominee, whose starred in films including Chinatown, was announced by her daughter Laura DernOscar-nominated actor Diane Ladd has died at the age of 89.The actor, whose credits included Alice Doesn’t Live Here Anymore, Chinatown and National Lampoon’s Christmas Vacation, died at her home in Ojai, California. The news was announced in a statement shared by her daughter, Oscar-winning actor Laura Dern. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Diane Ladd, a three-time Oscar-nominated actress, has died at age 89.
Her daughter, Laura Dern, announced her mother's death.
Ladd was known for roles in "Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore" and "Wild at Heart."
She appeared in several films with her daughter, Laura Dern.
Ladd received three Academy Award nominations during her career.

clusters.title: Trump threatens to pull federal funds for New York City if Zohran Mamdani wins mayoral election – live
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Threatens to Pull Funds for New York City

items.title: Trump threatens to pull federal funds for New York City if Zohran Mamdani wins mayoral election – live
items.standfirst: US president also backs independent candidate Andrew Cuomo, the former New York governor who resigned in disgraceLooking ahead, on Wednesday, the supreme court will hear arguments on whether Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs on dozens of countries are legal. It’s set to be one of the most consequential rulings on the expanse of Trump’s presidential power in his second term.My colleague, Eduardo Porter, has this helpful breakdown on the question at the heart of this case. A dozen states have challenged the president’s contention that the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) of 1977 gives him the power to impose tariffs on imports from every country in the world to defend the nation from a several “threats” facing the US.Justices will focus much of their attention on whether IEEPA authorizes the president to levy a tariff – a word that is not mentioned in the text of the law and is, moreover, a form of taxation, over which, per the constitution, Congress has exclusive power.IEEPA gives the president authority “to deal with any unusual and extraordinary threat, which has its source in whole or substantial part outside the United States, to the national security, foreign policy, or economy of the United States, if the president declares a national emergency with respect to such threat”. Continue reading...
items.content: US president also backs independent candidate Andrew Cuomo, the former New York governor who resigned in disgraceLooking ahead, on Wednesday, the supreme court will hear arguments on whether Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs on dozens of countries are legal. It’s set to be one of the most consequential rulings on the expanse of Trump’s presidential power in his second term.My colleague, Eduardo Porter, has this helpful breakdown on the question at the heart of this case. A dozen states have challenged the president’s contention that the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) of 1977 gives him the power to impose tariffs on imports from every country in the world to defend the nation from a several “threats” facing the US.Justices will focus much of their attention on whether IEEPA authorizes the president to levy a tariff – a word that is not mentioned in the text of the law and is, moreover, a form of taxation, over which, per the constitution, Congress has exclusive power.IEEPA gives the president authority “to deal with any unusual and extraordinary threat, which has its source in whole or substantial part outside the United States, to the national security, foreign policy, or economy of the United States, if the president declares a national emergency with respect to such threat”. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump 'allocating himself a power that he does not have' on tariffs, expert says
items.standfirst: The U.S. Supreme Court holds oral arguments on Wednesday over the legality of President Donald Trump's tariffs imposed under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. Speaking on FRANCE 24, Frederick T. Davis, Former Federal Prosecutor and Lecturer in Law at Columbia University, says that Trump 'is allocating himself a power that he does not have' and that the Supreme Court 'should say so'.

items.title: The president who cried tariffs: will the US supreme court challenge Trump’s trade war?
items.standfirst: The US high court will hear arguments on whether Trump’s erratic imposition of global tariffs is legally validDonald Trump thrives on emergencies. He cried havoc on the very first day of his second term, declaring a national emergency caused by an “invasion” of “illegal aliens” from Mexico. He has since invoked emergencies more than any president since the passage of the National Emergencies Act in 1976.Next Wednesday, he faces another of his own making, as the US supreme court hears oral arguments on whether his globe-shaking signature economic policy – tariffs – is legally valid. Continue reading...

Mazón acknowledged mistakes were made in handling the floods.
He faced daily calls for his resignation.
The resignation follows the devastating impact of the floods.

clusters.title: Trump says it would be 'hard for me' to fund New York City if Mamdani becomes mayor
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Comments on New York City Mayoral Race

items.title: Trump says it would be 'hard for me' to fund New York City if Mamdani becomes mayor
items.standfirst: Left-wing candidate Zohran Mamdani is leading many opinion polls in Tuesday's mayoral race.
items.content: Left-wing candidate Zohran Mamdani is leading many opinion polls in Tuesday's mayoral race.

items.title: Judge says Trump administration must fund SNAP. And, what to know about NYC's election
items.standfirst: Two judges have ordered the Trump administration to fund SNAP benefits. And, New York City voters head to the polls tomorrow to choose between Zohran Mamdani and former Gov. Andrew Cuomo in the mayoral race.
items.content: Two judges have ordered the Trump administration to fund SNAP benefits. And, New York City voters head to the polls tomorrow to choose between Zohran Mamdani and former Gov. Andrew Cuomo in the mayoral race.(Image credit: Aaron Schwartz)

ai_summary: Trump said it would be "hard for me" to fund New York City.
This statement was made if Zohran Mamdani becomes mayor.
Zohran Mamdani is leading in many opinion polls.
Two judges ordered the Trump administration to fund SNAP benefits.
New York City voters will choose a mayor soon.

clusters.title: Xi Jinping cracks joke about spying with phones given to South Korean president
clusters.neutral_headline: Xi Jinping cracks joke about spying with phones given to South Korean president

items.title: Xi Jinping cracks joke about spying with phones given to South Korean president
items.standfirst: Chinese leader says ‘check if there is a backdoor’ in reply to Lee Jae Myung’s quip about security of Xiaomi devices It would take someone with nerves of steel to joke about the security of Chinese smartphones in front of Xi Jinping.Step forward the South Korean president, Lee Jae Myung, who, after being given a pair of smartphones by the Chinese leader before their state banquet at the weekend, wondered out loud if the devices were secure. Continue reading...
items.content: Chinese leader says ‘check if there is a backdoor’ in reply to Lee Jae Myung’s quip about security of Xiaomi devices It would take someone with nerves of steel to joke about the security of Chinese smartphones in front of Xi Jinping.Step forward the South Korean president, Lee Jae Myung, who, after being given a pair of smartphones by the Chinese leader before their state banquet at the weekend, wondered out loud if the devices were secure. Continue reading...

items.title: Xi Quips About Backdoors During Xiaomi Phone Gift to Korea’s Lee
items.standfirst: Chinese President Xi Jinping joked about security backdoors while presenting a pair of Xiaomi Corp. smartphones to his South Korean counterpart, a rare moment of spontaneous levity captured during a week of tense trade negotiations with Donald Trump.
items.content: Chinese President Xi Jinping joked about security backdoors while presenting a pair of Xiaomi Corp. smartphones to his South Korean counterpart, a rare moment of spontaneous levity captured during a week of tense trade negotiations with Donald Trump.

ai_summary: Xi Jinping joked about security backdoors in Xiaomi phones.
He made the joke while giving phones to South Korea's Lee Jae Myung.
Lee Jae Myung questioned the security of the phones.
The event occurred during tense trade negotiations.
It was a rare moment of levity for Xi.

clusters.title: Mayor killed during Day Of The Dead festivities
clusters.neutral_headline: Mexican Mayor Killed During Day of the Dead

items.title: Mayor killed during Day Of The Dead festivities
items.standfirst: A mayor has been shot dead in front of dozens of people in Mexico during Day Of The Dead festivities.
items.content: A mayor has been shot dead in front of dozens of people in Mexico during Day Of The Dead festivities.

items.title: Mexican mayor killed during Day of the Dead celebrations
items.standfirst: Carlos Alberto Manzo Rodríguez, who was under police protection, was shot dead in front of dozens of peopleA mayor in Mexico’s western state of Michoacán was shot dead in a plaza in front of dozens of people who had gathered for Day of the Dead festivities, authorities have said.The mayor of the Uruapan municipality, Carlos Alberto Manzo Rodríguez, was gunned down Saturday night in the town’s historic centre. He was rushed to a hospital where he later died, according to state prosecutor Carlos Torres Piña. Continue reading...
items.content: Carlos Alberto Manzo Rodríguez, who was under police protection, was shot dead in front of dozens of peopleA mayor in Mexico’s western state of Michoacán was shot dead in a plaza in front of dozens of people who had gathered for Day of the Dead festivities, authorities have said.The mayor of the Uruapan municipality, Carlos Alberto Manzo Rodríguez, was gunned down Saturday night in the town’s historic centre. He was rushed to a hospital where he later died, according to state prosecutor Carlos Torres Piña. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A mayor was shot dead during Day of the Dead festivities.
The mayor was killed in Mexico's Michoacán state.
The mayor was shot in front of dozens of people.
The mayor was under police protection.
The mayor was rushed to a hospital but died.

clusters.title: Israel confirms Hamas returned bodies of three soldiers held hostage
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Confirms Hamas Returned Bodies of Soldiers

items.title: Israel confirms Hamas returned bodies of three soldiers held hostage
items.standfirst: Authorities identify the remains handed over on Sunday, bringing to eight the number of hostages' bodies still to be found in Gaza.
items.content: Authorities identify the remains handed over on Sunday, bringing to eight the number of hostages' bodies still to be found in Gaza.

items.title: Hamas returns bodies of 3 deceased hostages to Israel
items.standfirst: Hamas returned the bodies of three hostages to Israel on Sunday, with the International Committee of the Red Cross once again serving as an intermediary, officials said
items.content: Hamas returned the bodies of three hostages to Israel on Sunday, with the International Committee of the Red Cross once again serving as an intermediary, officials said

ai_summary: Israel confirmed Hamas returned bodies of three soldiers.
The bodies were handed over on Sunday.
Authorities identified the remains.
Eight hostages' bodies are still to be found in Gaza.
The International Committee of the Red Cross served as intermediary.
